private_information: I can observe and move blocks according to standard BlocksWorld rules: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
I am given the initial configuration and the first half of the action sequence (actions 1 to 25).
robot1.goal: Verify and report the state changes resulting from actions 1 to 25 and emit a concise observation trace summarizing the resulting partial world state.

private_information: I can observe and move blocks according to standard BlocksWorld rules: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
I am given the latter half of the action sequence (actions 26 to 50).
robot2.goal: Verify and report the state changes resulting from actions 26 to 50 and emit a concise observation trace summarizing the resulting world state after these actions.

private_information: I coordinate observations from robot1 and robot2 and produce the final planning instance for evaluation by the FastDownwards solver.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate reports from robot1 and robot2 and produce a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem that represent the final BlocksWorld configuration after the full action sequence, formatted for FastDownwards.

public_information: Blocks present: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K.
Standard BlocksWorld rules apply: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
Initial stacks from bottom to top are: Stack1: A, B, H, I. Stack2: C, F, J, K, G, E, D.
The action sequence of 50 ordered actions is provided and must be executed in order by the agents.

Action sequence: 1 unstack(I,H), 2 putdown(I), 3 pickup(I), 4 stack(I,H), 5 unstack(D,E), 6 stack(D,E), 7 unstack(D,E), 8 stack(D,I), 9 unstack(D,I), 10 stack(D,E), 11 unstack(I,H), 12 putdown(I), 13 unstack(H,B), 14 stack(H,I), 15 unstack(B,A), 16 putdown(B), 17 pickup(B), 18 stack(B,H), 19 pickup(A), 20 putdown(A), 21 pickup(A), 22 putdown(A), 23 pickup(A), 24 stack(A,B), 25 unstack(D,E), 26 putdown(D), 27 unstack(A,B), 28 stack(A,D), 29 unstack(B,H), 30 stack(B,H), 31 unstack(E,G), 32 putdown(E), 33 pickup(E), 34 stack(E,A), 35 unstack(G,K), 36 putdown(G), 37 unstack(B,H), 38 stack(B,H), 39 unstack(E,A), 40 stack(E,A), 41 pickup(G), 42 putdown(G), 43 unstack(K,J), 44 stack(K,G), 45 unstack(K,G), 46 stack(K,J), 47 pickup(G), 48 putdown(G), 49 unstack(B,H), 50 stack(B,G).

Final arrangement derived from executing the full sequence in order is: A is on D, B is on G, C is on the table, D is on the table, E is on A, F is on C, G is on the table, H is on I, I is on the table, J is on F, K is on J.

observe.system_prompt: You are a blocks manipulation robot that verifies and records execution of a sequence of BlocksWorld actions. Do not emit PDDL. Provide a concise and precise observation trace describing the effect of each action you are given and the partial world state after action 25.
observe.prompt: You are robot1. Use the public information about the blocks and the initial configuration. You have these private details: the BlocksWorld rules and actions 1 to 25 of the sequence. Execute actions 1 to 25 in order under standard BlocksWorld semantics and report any illegal actions if they occur. Output a concise trace of state changes and the world state after action 25 in the form of stacks bottom-to-top.

observe.system_prompt: You are a blocks manipulation robot that verifies and records execution of a sequence of BlocksWorld actions. Do not emit PDDL. Provide a concise and precise observation trace describing the effect of each action you are given and the resulting world state after completing actions 26 to 50 when applied after robot1's actions.
observe.prompt: You are robot2. Use the public information and assume robot1 has executed actions 1 to 25 correctly unless you detect contradictions. You have these private details: actions 26 to 50 of the sequence. Execute actions 26 to 50 in order and report any illegal actions if they occur. Output a concise trace of state changes and the final world state after action 50 in the form of stacks bottom-to-top.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an orchestrator that must integrate observation traces from multiple agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem suitable for solving with the FastDownwards planner. You must produce both the PDDL domain and PDDL problem files. Enclose the domain between <domain> and </domain> tags and the problem between <problem> and </problem> tags. The PDDL should represent the BlocksWorld domain and the final world state after the executed actions. Target the FastDownwards solver when producing requirements and the format.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You will receive the concise observation traces from robot1 and robot2 as described in their outputs. Integrate both traces into a single consistent final world state. Then produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem representing the BlocksWorld domain and the final state as the initial state in the problem file. The goal in the PDDL problem should be left general or set to a sample goal if none is required, but the initial state must match the final arrangement derived from the observations. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Ensure the PDDL is compatible with FastDownwards.
